newsitem.title: UK: Firms should be wary of new copper mines - report.
newsitem.headline: Firms should be wary of new copper mines - report.

text.p: Mining companies should be cautious of building new copper mines since an era of high prices seems to be ending, a report by industrial consultant CRU International said.

"With the current run of high copper prices likely to be nearing its end, mining companies and financiers need to look very carefully at the economic and technical viability of the projects they are involved in," CRU said.
The CRU report examined 20 projects which could account for almost three million tonnes of new copper production per year with total capital expenditure in excess of $13 billion.
"Only five of the 20 major projects examined can be categorised as sure-fire winners," it added.
CRU rates the Voisey's Bay project, where copper is a by-product of nickel, as the most viable project. The proposed start-up date of the project, operated by Canada's Inco, is 1999.

The second most attractive project and the biggest is Collahuasi in Chile, in which Canada's Falconbridge Ltd has a 44 percent interest. The internal rate of return is well in excess of 15 percent with a payback period of four years, CRU said.

The calculations assume a long-term copper price of 90 cents per lb ($1,984 per tonne) but Collahuasi would generate a positive return even if prices fell as low as 75 cent per lb ($1,654 per tonne), it said.
